titlestmt.titleproper: ARCHIVES OF THE TRANSVAAL ASIATIC LAND TENURE ACT COMMITTEE

did.unittitle: ARCHIVES OF THE TRANSVAAL ASIATIC LAND TENURE ACT COMMITTEE

origination.corpname: THE TRANSVAAL ASIATIC LAND TENURE ACT COMMITTEE

repository.corpname: National Archives and Records Service of South Africa

address.addressline: 24 Hamilton street Pretoria Gauteng South Africa 0001 Telephone: +27124413200 Fax: +27123235287 Email: enquiries@dac.gov.za http://www.national.archives.gov.za South Africa

bioghist.p: This Committee was appointed in terms of Section 3 of Act No. 32 of 1937; the Act empowered the Minister of the Interior to appoint a committee after the dissolution of the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Commission (Feetham Commission).1 The powers of this Committee are confined to: a) To investigate and report on any matter arising from the Commission report and recommendations which may be referred to it by the Minister b) The duties conferred upon the Committee under section 131A (4) of the Gold Law as substituted by section 5 of Act No. 30 of 1936.2 The Asiatic Land Tenure Act Committee was a statutory body and the ambit of its functions was strictly limited by the statute under which it was appointed. An analysis of these two functions mentioned above reveals that any matter which does not fall within the terms of reference of the Feetham Commission was outside the scope of this Committee. The Feetham Commission’s terms of reference were confined to land proclaimed under the Gold Law.3 The Minister of the Interior, on 11th October 1943, made it clear that the Committee should confine its activities: • To completing all matters arising out of the Feetham Commission’s recommendations. • To making recommendations for extending the blocks of lots in townships already permanently exempted. • That the Committee’s recommendations for exemptions of individual cases must be on a qualified and terminable basis.4 The original members of the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Committee were as follows: • Mr. P.F. Kincaid ( Chairman ) • Mr. D.J. Stewart ( Former member of Feetham Commission) • Mr. H. Geake (Secretary).5 After the first Committee meeting on 26 July 1937, the following members were appointed: • Mr. P.F. Kincaid (Chairman) – Commissioner for Immigration and Asiatic Affairs • Mr. D.S. Van der Merwe (additional member) – Assistant-Registrar of Mining Titles • Mr. T.H.V. Hönck ( Secretary) - Department of the Interior • Mr. H. Britten – Magistrate of Johannesburg.6 With the passing of Act No. 28 of 1946 (Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representative Act, 1946), the Committee was dissolved, and its functions taken over by the newly established Land Advisory Board.7

An analysis of these two functions mentioned above reveals that any matter which does not fall within the terms of reference of the Feetham Commission was outside the scope of this Committee. The Feetham Commission’s terms of reference were confined to land proclaimed under the Gold Law.3 The Minister of the Interior, on 11th October 1943, made it clear that the Committee should confine its activities: • To completing all matters arising out of the Feetham Commission’s recommendations. • To making recommendations for extending the blocks of lots in townships already permanently exempted. • That the Committee’s recommendations for exemptions of individual cases must be on a qualified and terminable basis.4 The original members of the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Committee were as follows: • Mr. P.F. Kincaid (Chairman) – Commissioner for Immigration and Asiatic Affairs • Mr. D.S. Van der Merwe (additional member) – Assistant-Registrar of Mining Titles • Mr. T.H.V. Hönck ( Secretary) - Department of the Interior • Mr. H. controlaccess.corpname: THE TRANSVAAL ASIATIC LAND TENURE ACT COMMITTEE

custodhist.p: This Committee was appointed in terms of Section 3 of Act No. 32 of 1937; the Act empowered the Minister of the Interior to appoint a committee after the dissolution of the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Commission (Feetham Commission).1 The powers of this Committee are confined to: a) To investigate and report on any matter arising from the Commission report and recommendations which may be referred to it by the Minister b) The duties conferred upon the Committee under section 131A (4) of the Gold Law as substituted by section 5 of Act No. 30 of 1936.2 The Asiatic Land Tenure Act Committee was a statutory body and the ambit of its functions was strictly limited by the statute under which it was appointed. An analysis of these two functions mentioned above reveals that any matter which does not fall within the terms of reference of the Feetham Commission was outside the scope of this Committee. The Feetham Commission’s terms of reference were confined to land proclaimed under the Gold Law.3 The Minister of the Interior, on 11th October 1943, made it clear that the Committee should confine its activities: • To completing all matters arising out of the Feetham Commission’s recommendations. • To making recommendations for extending the blocks of lots in townships already permanently exempted. • That the Committee’s recommendations for exemptions of individual cases must be on a qualified and terminable basis.4 The original members of the Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Act Committee were as follows: • Mr. P.F. Kincaid ( Chairman ) • Mr. D.J. Stewart ( Former member of Feetham Commission) • Mr. H. Geake (Secretary).5 After the first Committee meeting on 26 July 1937, the following members were appointed: • Mr. P.F. Kincaid (Chairman) – Commissioner for Immigration and Asiatic Affairs • Mr. D.S. Van der Merwe (additional member) – Assistant-Registrar of Mining Titles • Mr. T.H.V. Hönck ( Secretary) - Department of the Interior • Mr. H. Britten – Magistrate of Johannesburg.6 With the passing of Act No. 28 of 1946 (Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representative Act, 1946), the Committee was dissolved, and its functions taken over by the newly established Land Advisory Board.7

accessrestrict.p: In terms of the National Archives and Records Service of South Africa Act (Act No. 43 of 1996, as amended) these records are accessible for research.

otherfindaid.p: Related primary material to view: • BNS: Secretary of Home Affairs, 1899 - 1973 • K118: Asiatic Land Tenure Act Commission, 1932 -1937 • CIA: Commissioner for Immigration and Asiatic Affairs, 1913 -1965 • ARG: Land Tenure Advisory Board, 1932 - 1959

did.unittitle: Letters to Secretary for the Interior
Correspondence re licenses and license application
Complaint to Prime Minister coloured people in Burgersdorp
Asiatic Traders expelled from prospect township
Memoranda by M van der Merwe
The Transvaal Asiatic Land Tenure Amendment Act No. 30 of 1936: memorandum by Leslie Blackwell KC.MP

scopecontent.p: File sequence has frequent gaps, file A.C.22, A.C.27, A.C.31, A.C.32 and A.C.22 are missing

did.unittitle: Judgement by Millan, J in the case of Samuel Goldburg V Kingswood fruit market stand
Memoranda by Messrs H Britten and DS van der Merwe on applications for removal from old sites to other sites
Glean Leary report on alteration of boundaries of Randfontein Municipality
Indian Ownership in Martindale, Newclare and Sophiatown – representation by Indian population
